definitions.example: a fast woman

definitions.definition: Ahead of the correct time or schedule.
definitions.example: There must be something wrong with the hall clock. It is always fast.

definitions.definition: (of photographic film) More sensitive to light than average.
In a firm or secure manner, securely; in such a way as not to be moved; safe, sound .
definitions.example: Hold this rope as fast as you can.

definitions.definition: (of sleeping) Deeply or soundly .
definitions.example: He is fast asleep.

definitions.definition: Immediately following in place or time; close, very near .
definitions.example: Fast by the sturdy batsman the ball unheeded sped. / That ain't my style, said Casey. Strike one, the umpire said.

definitions.definition: Quickly, with great speed; within a short time .
definitions.example: Do it as fast as you can.

definitions.definition: Ahead of the correct time or schedule.
definitions.example: I think my watch is running fast.

definitions.definition: Short for "stand fast", a warning not to pass between the arrow and the target
The act or practice of abstaining from food or of eating very little food.
The period of time during which one abstains from or eats very little food.
definitions.example: Lent and Ramadan are fasts of two religions.

definitions.definition: To restrict one’s personal consumption, generally of food, but sometimes other things, in various manners (totally, temporally, by avoiding particular items), often for religious or medical reasons.
definitions.example: Muslims fast during Ramadan and Catholics during Lent.

definitions.definition: Someone or something wished for.
definitions.example: It is my desire to speak with you.

definitions.definition: Strong attraction, particularly romantic or sexual.
definitions.example: His desire for her kept him awake at night.

definitions.definition: The feeling of desiring; an eager longing for something.
definitions.example: Too much desire can seriously affect one’s judgment.

definitions.definition: Motivation.
To want; to wish for earnestly.
definitions.example: I desire to speak with you.

definitions.definition: To put a request to (someone); to entreat.
To want emotionally or sexually.
definitions.example: She has desired him since they first met.

definitions.definition: To express a wish for; to entreat; to request.
To require; to demand; to claim.
To miss; to regret.
The act of hunting.
A hunting expedition.
An organization devoted to hunting, or the people belonging to it.
A pack of hunting dogs.
To find or search for an animal in the wild with the intention of killing the animal for its meat or for sport.
definitions.example: Her uncle will go out and hunt for deer, now that it is open season.

definitions.definition: To try to find something; search (for).
definitions.example: The little girl was hunting for shells on the beach.

definitions.definition: To drive; to chase; with down, from, away, etc.
definitions.example: He was hunted from the parish.

definitions.definition: To use or manage (dogs, horses, etc.) in hunting.
definitions.example: Did you hunt that pony last week?

definitions.definition: To use or traverse in pursuit of game.
definitions.example: He hunts the woods, or the country.

definitions.definition: (bell-ringing) To move or shift the order of (a bell) in a regular course of changes.
(bell-ringing) To shift up and down in order regularly.

To be in a state of instability of movement or forced oscillation, as a governor which has a large movement of the balls for small change of load, an arc-lamp clutch mechanism which moves rapidly up and down with variations of current, etc.; also, to seesaw, as a pair of alternators working in parallel.
The shore of a body of water, especially when sandy or pebbly.
A horizontal strip of land, usually sandy, adjoining water.
The loose pebbles of the seashore, especially worn by waves; shingle.
To run aground on a beach.
To run (something) aground on a beach.
(of a vehicle) To run into an obstacle or rough or soft ground, so that the floor of the vehicle rests on the ground and the wheels cannot gain traction.
A gravel-filled zone on a racetrack, used as a hazard, exclusionary region, and, safety device to slow down and trap vehicles.
The act of applying or laying on, in a literal sense
definitions.example: The application of this cream should reduce the swelling.

definitions.definition: The substance applied.
The act of applying as a means; the employment of means to accomplish an end; specific use.
The act of directing or referring something to a particular case, to discover or illustrate agreement or disagreement, fitness, or correspondence.
definitions.example: I make the remark, and leave you to make the application.

definitions.definition: A computer program or the set of software that the end user perceives as a single entity as a tool for a well-defined purpose. (Also called: application program; application software.)
definitions.example: This iPhone application can connect to most social networks.

definitions.definition: A verbal or written request for assistance or employment or admission to a school, course or similar.
definitions.example: December 31 is the deadline for MBA applications.

definitions.definition: (bureaucracy) A petition, entreaty, or other request, with the adposition for denoting the subject matter.
definitions.example: Their application for a deferral of the hearing was granted.

definitions.definition: The act of requesting, claiming, or petitioning something.
Diligence; close thought or attention.
A kind of needlework; appliqué.
Compliance.
A (male) ruler, a sovereign; a king, monarch.
A female monarch.
Someone who is preeminent in their field; a great person.
definitions.example: He is a prince among men.

definitions.definition: The (male) ruler or head of a principality.
A male member of a royal family other than the ruler; especially (in the United Kingdom) the son or grandson of the monarch.
A non-royal high title of nobility, especially in France and the Holy Roman Empire.
definitions.example: Prince Louis de Broglie won the 1929 Nobel Prize in Physics.

definitions.definition: The mushroom Agaricus augustus.
A type of court card used in tarot cards, the equivalent of the jack.
Any of various nymphalid butterflies of the genus Rohana.
A strip of material used for strengthening or coupling.
A long strip of material, color, etc, that is different from the surrounding area.
A strip of decoration.
That which serves as the means of union or connection between persons; a tie.
A linen collar or ruff worn in the 16th and 17th centuries.
(in the plural) Two strips of linen hanging from the neck in front as part of a clerical, legal, or academic dress.
A part of the electromagnetic spectrum.
A group of energy levels in a solid state material.
definitions.example: valence band;  conduction band

definitions.definition: A bond.
Pledge; security.
A ring, such as a wedding ring (wedding band), or a ring put on a bird's leg to identify it.
Any distinguishing line formed by chromatography, electrophoresis etc
Short for band cell.
(hiphop, often in the plural) A wad of money totaling $1K, held together by a band; (by extension) money
To fasten with a band.
To fasten an identifying band around the leg of (a bird).
A group of musicians who perform together as an ensemble, usually for a professional recording artist.
A type of orchestra originally playing janissary music.
A marching band.
A group of people loosely united for a common purpose (a band of thieves).
A small group of people living in a simple society, contrasted with tribes, chiefdoms, and states.
A group of aboriginals that has official recognition as an organized unit by the federal government of Canada.
To group together for a common purpose; to confederate.
To group (students) together by perceived ability; to stream.
To tie; to confine by any ligature.
To cohere or stick together in a mass.
definitions.example: Just to make the cheese more binding

definitions.definition: To be restrained from motion, or from customary or natural action, as by friction.
definitions.example: I wish I knew why the sewing machine binds up after I use it for a while.

definitions.definition: To exert a binding or restraining influence.
definitions.example: These are the ties that bind.

definitions.definition: To tie or fasten tightly together, with a cord, band, ligature, chain, etc.
definitions.example: to bind grain in bundles  to bind a prisoner

definitions.definition: To confine, restrain, or hold by physical force or influence of any kind.
definitions.example: Frost binds the earth.

definitions.definition: To couple.
To oblige, restrain, or hold, by authority, law, duty, promise, vow, affection, or other social tie.
definitions.example: to bind the conscience  to bind by kindness  bound by affection  commerce binds nations to each other

definitions.definition: To put (a person) under definite legal obligations, especially, under the obligation of a bond or covenant.
To place under legal obligation to serve.
definitions.example: to bind an apprentice  bound out to service

definitions.definition: To protect or strengthen by applying a band or binding, as the edge of a carpet or garment.
To make fast (a thing) about or upon something, as by tying; to encircle with something.
definitions.example: to bind a belt about one  to bind a compress upon a wound

definitions.definition: To cover, as with a bandage.
definitions.example: to bind up a wound

definitions.definition: To prevent or restrain from customary or natural action, as by producing constipation.
definitions.example: Certain drugs bind the bowels.

definitions.definition: To put together in a cover, as of books.
definitions.example: The three novels were bound together.

definitions.definition: To make two or more elements stick together.
To associate an identifier with a value; to associate a variable name, method name, etc. with the content of a storage location.
To complain; to whine about something.
An inclination in a particular direction.
definitions.example: the trend of a coastline

definitions.definition: A tendency.
definitions.example: There is a trend, these days, for people in films not to smoke.

definitions.definition: A fad or fashion style.
definitions.example: Miniskirts were one of the biggest trends of the 1960s.

definitions.definition: A line drawn on a graph that approximates the trend of a number of disparate points.
The lower end of the shank of an anchor, being the same distance on the shank from the throat that the arm measures from the throat to the bill.
The angle made by the line of a vessel's keel and the direction of the anchor cable, when she is swinging at anchor.
To have a particular direction; to run; to stretch; to tend.
definitions.example: The shore of the sea trends to the southwest.

definitions.definition: To cause to turn; to bend.
To be the subject of a trend; to be currently popular, relevant or interesting.
definitions.example: What topics have been trending on social networks this week?

definitions.definition: Clean wool.
To cleanse or clean (something, usually wool).
(usually in the plural) That which is deserved or merited; a just punishment or reward
A barren area of land or desolate terrain, especially one with little water or vegetation; a wasteland.
Any barren place or situation.
Usually of a place: abandoned, deserted, or uninhabited.
definitions.example: They were marooned on a desert island in the Pacific.

definitions.definition: To leave (anything that depends on one's presence to survive, exist, or succeed), especially when contrary to a promise or obligation; to abandon; to forsake.
definitions.example: You can't just drive off and desert me here, in the middle of nowhere.

definitions.definition: To leave one's duty or post, especially to leave a military or naval unit without permission.
definitions.example: Anyone found deserting will be punished.

definitions.definition: State or condition of not meeting a desirable or intended objective, opposite of success.
An object, person or endeavour in a state of failure or incapable of success.
Termination of the ability of an item to perform its required function; breakdown.
Bankruptcy.
An opening in anything made by breaking or parting.
definitions.example: He made a gap in the fence by kicking at a weak spot.

definitions.definition: An opening allowing passage or entrance.
definitions.example: We can slip through that gap between the buildings.

definitions.definition: An opening that implies a breach or defect.
definitions.example: There is a gap between the roof and the gutter.

definitions.definition: A vacant space or time.
definitions.example: I have a gap in my schedule next Tuesday.

definitions.definition: A hiatus, a pause in something which is otherwise continuous.
definitions.example: I'm taking a gap.

definitions.definition: A vacancy, deficit, absence, or lack.
definitions.example: Find words to fill the gaps in an incomplete sentence.

definitions.definition: A mountain or hill pass.
definitions.example: The exploring party went through the high gap in the mountains.

definitions.definition: A sheltered area of coast between two cliffs (mostly restricted to place names).
definitions.example: At Birling Gap we can stop and go have a picnic on the beach.

definitions.definition: The regions between the outfielders.
definitions.example: Jones doubled through the gap.

definitions.definition: (for a medical or pharmacy item) The shortfall between the amount the medical insurer will pay to the service provider and the scheduled fee for the item.
(usually written as "the gap") The disparity between the indigenous and non-indigenous communities with regard to life expectancy, education, health, etc.
An unsequenced region in a sequence alignment.
To notch, as a sword or knife.
To make an opening in; to breach.
To check the size of a gap.
definitions.example: I gapped all the spark plugs in my car, but then realized I had used the wrong manual and had made them too small.

definitions.definition: To leave suddenly.
An elected head of a gewog in Bhutan.
Most of the time; less than always, but more than occasionally.
definitions.example: Except for one or two days a year, he usually walks to work.

definitions.definition: Under normal conditions.
A pedestrianised street, especially a shopping precinct.
An enclosed shopping centre.
An alley where the game of pall mall was played.
A public walk; a level shaded walk, a promenade.
A heavy wooden mallet or hammer used in the game of pall mall.
The game of polo.
An old game played with malls or mallets and balls; pall mall.
To beat with a mall, or mallet; to beat with something heavy; to bruise
To build up with the development of shopping malls
To shop at the mall
Causing attraction; having the quality of attracting by inherent force.
Having the power of charming or alluring by agreeable qualities; enticing.
definitions.example: That's a very attractive offer.

definitions.definition: Pleasing or appealing to the senses, especially of the opposite sex.
definitions.example: He is an attractive fellow with a trim figure.
